content:
There’s a great idea: this tool “PPT Presentation Video to Transcript + Images” could be used to generate high-quality datasets!

The Flamingo dataset contains video texts and web multimodal texts. However, it consists of short videos, averaging only 22 seconds, so it definitely can’t achieve fine-grained information. It’s likely a combination of video and video descriptions. Today, I can do it! b3aca2da675d67feb7e3d0977cb1381a

Here are the key steps:

Extract keyframes from the video to create a list of PPT images. If the difference between each frame and the previous one exceeds a certain threshold, it’s considered a transition to a new PPT slide. An open-source software like video2pdf can handle this. OCR each image into text. Since they are printed characters, the recognition accuracy is very high, and Tesseract can be used for this. Extract the audio track that stays on each PPT slide and feed it to a Speech-to-Text model for recognition. For example, I use the Whisper model open-sourced by OpenAI. (The final step is crucial) Let a large language model (e.g., GPT-4) correct the transcription recognized by the Speech-to-Text model based on the OCR’d current slide content and the content of the first slide. The Speech-to-Text model currently has a low accuracy in recognizing proper nouns and names, but many of these proper nouns have appeared on this PPT slide, and the first slide of the PPT also defines the title and domain of the presentation. Therefore, with the content of the PPT as a reference, the large language model can correct most of the recognition errors of proper nouns. Without the content of the PPT as a reference, GPT-4 is needed to correct most of the proper nouns, but with the PPT content, LLaMA-2-70b-chat is sufficient. Additionally, the large language model can correct colloquial expressions in the speech, making the transcript more rigorous and readable. The following transcript is completely generated automatically, with only a few names unchanged. Of course, some minor errors have been retained, but they are all harmless. The Video2PDF, Tesseract, Whisper, and LLaMA-2-70b-chat models used in the entire process are running on my own MacBook laptop without the need for an internet connection.
title: convert PowerPoint Presentation video to images and captions

Mathjax

Math equations can be rendered using Mathjax syntax with AMS symbol support.

Optionally enable this on a per-page basis by adding mathjax: true to your frontmatter.

Then, use $$ ... $$ on a line by itself to render a block equation:

$$ | Pr_{x \leftarrow P_{1}} [A(x) = 1] - Pr_{x \leftarrow P_{2}} [A(x) = 1] | < \text{negligible} $$

The raw version is:

$$ | Pr_{x \leftarrow P_{1}} [A(x) = 1] - Pr_{x \leftarrow P_{2}} [A(x) = 1] | < \text{negligible} $$

Write in-line equations with \\( ... \\) , like \( x^n / y \) . It’s easy!

Emoji can be enabled in a Hugo project in a number of ways. :zap:

Emoji Support

The emojify function can be called directly in templates or Inline Shortcodes.

To enable emoji globally, set enableEmoji to true in your site’s configuration and then you can type emoji shorthand codes directly in content files; e.g.

The Emoji cheat sheet is a useful reference for emoji shorthand codes.

N.B. The above steps enable Unicode Standard emoji characters and sequences in Hugo, however the rendering of these glyphs depends on the browser and the platform. To style the emoji you can either use a third party emoji font or a font stack; e.g.

.emoji {
  font-family: Apple Color Emoji, Segoe UI Emoji, NotoColorEmoji, Segoe UI Symbol, Android Emoji, EmojiSymbols;
}
